comment_text.mn78:1.3: Uggāhamāna appears to have the sense “argumentative” found in the Sanskrit udgrāha but not otherwise attested in Pali. Both sense and reading of Samaṇamaṇḍikā are unclear. He appears nowhere else. | Mallikā was the chief queen of Pasenadi, and her place is mentioned in a similar context at DN 9:1.3. The commentary explains that the brahmins, Jains, and others would assemble there to “debate their beliefs” (samayaṁ pavadanti), a rare early usage of samaya in this sense. | Read ācīra in the sense of “boundary, hedge” (Commentary: timbarūrukkhapantiyā parikkhittattā; cf. Sanskrit prācīra, “enclosure, hedge, fence, wall”).
comment_text.mn78:5.1: The “invincible ascetic” (samaṇaṁ ayojjhaṁ) appears only here. The Sanskrit ayodhya occurs in the Atharva Veda as an epithet of Indra (19.13.7) and of the gods’ “impregnable” fortress (10.2.31). It seems to be a special term for an enlightened being in Uggāhamāna’s system; compare Upaka’s “Infinite Victor” (anantajina) of MN 26:25.22.
comment_text.mn78:11.12: Taking the suffix -maya in the same sense as tammaya; see my note on MN 47:13.4. The point is that they are not formed by and hence limited by the scope of ethics.

root_text.mn78:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn78:1.3: Tena kho pana samayena uggāhamāno paribbājako samaṇamuṇḍikāputto samayappavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ pañcamattehi paribbājakasatehi.
root_text.mn78:2.1: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati sāvatthiyā nikkhami divā divassa bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
root_text.mn78:2.7: Yannūnāhaṁ yena samayappavādako tindukācīro ekasālako mallikāya ārāmo yena uggāhamāno paribbājako samaṇamuṇḍikāputto tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
root_text.mn78:2.8: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati yena samayappavādako tindukācīro ekasālako mallikāya ārāmo yena uggāhamāno paribbājako samaṇamuṇḍikāputto tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn78:3.1: Tena kho pana samayena uggāhamāno paribbājako samaṇamuṇḍikāputto mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ nisinno hoti unnādiniyā uccāsaddamahāsaddāya anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ kathentiyā, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn78:3.2: rājakathaṁ corakathaṁ mahāmattakathaṁ senākathaṁ bhayakathaṁ yuddhakathaṁ annakathaṁ pānakathaṁ vatthakathaṁ sayanakathaṁ mālākathaṁ gandhakathaṁ ñātikathaṁ yānakathaṁ gāmakathaṁ nigamakathaṁ nagarakathaṁ janapadakathaṁ itthikathaṁ sūrakathaṁ visikhākathaṁ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṁ pubbapetakathaṁ nānattakathaṁ lokakkhāyikaṁ samuddakkhāyikaṁ itibhavābhavakathaṁ iti vā.
root_text.mn78:3.3: Addasā kho uggāhamāno paribbājako samaṇamuṇḍikāputto pañcakaṅgaṁ thapatiṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.mn78:3.6: ayaṁ samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako āgacchati pañcakaṅgo thapati.
root_text.mn78:3.7: Yāvatā kho pana samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā sāvatthiyaṁ paṭivasanti ayaṁ tesaṁ aññataro pañcakaṅgo thapati.
root_text.mn78:3.8: Appasaddakāmā kho pana te āyasmanto appasaddavinītā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādino;
root_text.mn78:3.9: appeva nāma appasaddaṁ parisaṁ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṁ maññeyyā”ti.
root_text.mn78:3.10: Atha kho te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
root_text.mn78:4.1: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati yena uggāhamāno paribbājako samaṇamuṇḍikāputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā uggāhamānena paribbājakena samaṇamuṇḍikāputtena saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn78:4.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho pañcakaṅgaṁ thapatiṁ uggāhamāno paribbājako samaṇamuṇḍikāputto etadavoca:
root_text.mn78:5.1: “catūhi kho ahaṁ, gahapati, dhammehi samannāgataṁ purisapuggalaṁ paññapemi sampannakusalaṁ paramakusalaṁ uttamapattipattaṁ samaṇaṁ ayojjhaṁ.
root_text.mn78:5.3: Idha, gahapati, na kāyena pāpakammaṁ karoti, na pāpakaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati, na pāpakaṁ saṅkappaṁ saṅkappeti, na pāpakaṁ ājīvaṁ ājīvati—
root_text.mn78:5.4: imehi kho ahaṁ, gahapati, catūhi dhammehi samannāgataṁ purisapuggalaṁ paññapemi sampannakusalaṁ paramakusalaṁ uttamapattipattaṁ samaṇaṁ ayojjhan”ti.
root_text.mn78:6.1: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati uggāhamānassa paribbājakassa samaṇamuṇḍikāputtassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandi nappaṭikkosi.
root_text.mn78:7.1: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn78:7.2: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho pañcakaṅgo thapati yāvatako ahosi uggāhamānena paribbājakena samaṇamuṇḍikāputtena saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
root_text.mn78:8.1: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā pañcakaṅgaṁ thapatiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn78:8.2: “evaṁ sante kho, thapati, daharo kumāro mando uttānaseyyako sampannakusalo bhavissati paramakusalo uttamapattipatto samaṇo ayojjho, yathā uggāhamānassa paribbājakassa samaṇamuṇḍikāputtassa vacanaṁ.
root_text.mn78:8.3: Daharassa hi, thapati, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa kāyotipi na hoti, kuto pana kāyena pāpakammaṁ karissati, aññatra phanditamattā.
root_text.mn78:8.4: Daharassa hi, thapati, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa vācātipi na hoti, kuto pana pāpakaṁ vācaṁ bhāsissati, aññatra roditamattā.
root_text.mn78:8.5: Daharassa hi, thapati, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa saṅkappotipi na hoti, kuto pana pāpakaṁ saṅkappaṁ saṅkappissati, aññatra vikūjitamattā.
root_text.mn78:8.6: Daharassa hi, thapati, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa ājīvotipi na hoti, kuto pana pāpakaṁ ājīvaṁ ājīvissati, aññatra mātuthaññā.
root_text.mn78:8.7: Evaṁ sante kho, thapati, daharo kumāro mando uttānaseyyako sampannakusalo bhavissati paramakusalo uttamapattipatto samaṇo ayojjho, yathā uggāhamānassa paribbājakassa samaṇamuṇḍikāputtassa vacanaṁ.
root_text.mn78:8.8: Catūhi kho ahaṁ, thapati, dhammehi samannāgataṁ purisapuggalaṁ paññapemi na ceva sampannakusalaṁ na paramakusalaṁ na uttamapattipattaṁ samaṇaṁ ayojjhaṁ, api cimaṁ daharaṁ kumāraṁ mandaṁ uttānaseyyakaṁ samadhigayha tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn78:8.10: Idha, thapati, na kāyena pāpakammaṁ karoti, na pāpakaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati, na pāpakaṁ saṅkappaṁ saṅkappeti, na pāpakaṁ ājīvaṁ ājīvati—
root_text.mn78:8.11: imehi kho ahaṁ, thapati, catūhi dhammehi samannāgataṁ purisapuggalaṁ paññapemi na ceva sampannakusalaṁ na paramakusalaṁ na uttamapattipattaṁ samaṇaṁ ayojjhaṁ, api cimaṁ daharaṁ kumāraṁ mandaṁ uttānaseyyakaṁ samadhigayha tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn78:9.1: Dasahi kho ahaṁ, thapati, dhammehi samannāgataṁ purisapuggalaṁ paññapemi sampannakusalaṁ paramakusalaṁ uttamapattipattaṁ samaṇaṁ ayojjhaṁ.
root_text.mn78:9.8: Evaṁ paṭipanno akusalānaṁ sīlānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti;
root_text.mn78:9.16: Evaṁ paṭipanno kusalānaṁ sīlānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti;
root_text.mn78:9.24: Evaṁ paṭipanno akusalānaṁ saṅkappānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti;
root_text.mn78:9.32: Evaṁ paṭipanno kusalānaṁ saṅkappānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti;
root_text.mn78:10.2: Akusalaṁ kāyakammaṁ, akusalaṁ vacīkammaṁ, pāpako ājīvo—
root_text.mn78:10.4: Ime ca, thapati, akusalā sīlā kiṁsamuṭṭhānā?
root_text.mn78:10.9: Yaṁ cittaṁ sarāgaṁ sadosaṁ samohaṁ, itosamuṭṭhānā akusalā sīlā.
root_text.mn78:10.10: Ime ca, thapati, akusalā sīlā kuhiṁ aparisesā nirujjhanti?
root_text.mn78:10.12: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu kāyaduccaritaṁ pahāya kāyasucaritaṁ bhāveti, vacīduccaritaṁ pahāya vacīsucaritaṁ bhāveti, manoduccaritaṁ pahāya manosucaritaṁ bhāveti, micchājīvaṁ pahāya sammājīvena jīvitaṁ kappeti—
root_text.mn78:10.14: Kathaṁ paṭipanno, thapati, akusalānaṁ sīlānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti?
root_text.mn78:10.15: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
root_text.mn78:10.16: uppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
root_text.mn78:10.17: anuppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ uppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
root_text.mn78:10.18: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
root_text.mn78:10.19: Evaṁ paṭipanno kho, thapati, akusalānaṁ sīlānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
root_text.mn78:11.2: Kusalaṁ kāyakammaṁ, kusalaṁ vacīkammaṁ, ājīvaparisuddhampi kho ahaṁ, thapati, sīlasmiṁ vadāmi.
root_text.mn78:11.4: Ime ca, thapati, kusalā sīlā kiṁsamuṭṭhānā?
root_text.mn78:11.9: Yaṁ cittaṁ vītarāgaṁ vītadosaṁ vītamohaṁ, itosamuṭṭhānā kusalā sīlā.
root_text.mn78:11.10: Ime ca, thapati, kusalā sīlā kuhiṁ aparisesā nirujjhanti?
root_text.mn78:11.12: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti no ca sīlamayo,
root_text.mn78:11.13: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti; yatthassa te kusalā sīlā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
root_text.mn78:11.14: Kathaṁ paṭipanno ca, thapati, kusalānaṁ sīlānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti?
root_text.mn78:11.15: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
root_text.mn78:11.18: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
root_text.mn78:11.19: Evaṁ paṭipanno kho, thapati, kusalānaṁ sīlānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
root_text.mn78:12.4: Ime ca, thapati, akusalā saṅkappā kiṁsamuṭṭhānā?
root_text.mn78:12.11: Ime ca, thapati, akusalā saṅkappā kuhiṁ aparisesā nirujjhanti?
root_text.mn78:12.13: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
root_text.mn78:12.15: Kathaṁ paṭipanno ca, thapati, akusalānaṁ saṅkappānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti?
root_text.mn78:12.16: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
root_text.mn78:12.19: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
root_text.mn78:12.20: Evaṁ paṭipanno kho, thapati, akusalānaṁ saṅkappānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
root_text.mn78:13.4: Ime ca, thapati, kusalā saṅkappā kiṁsamuṭṭhānā?
root_text.mn78:13.11: Ime ca, thapati, kusalā saṅkappā kuhiṁ aparisesā nirujjhanti?
root_text.mn78:13.13: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
root_text.mn78:13.15: Kathaṁ paṭipanno ca, thapati, kusalānaṁ saṅkappānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti?
root_text.mn78:13.16: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
root_text.mn78:13.19: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
root_text.mn78:13.20: Evaṁ paṭipanno kho, thapati, kusalānaṁ saṅkappānaṁ nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
root_text.mn78:14.1: Katamehi cāhaṁ, thapati, dasahi dhammehi samannāgataṁ purisapuggalaṁ paññapemi sampannakusalaṁ paramakusalaṁ uttamapattipattaṁ samaṇaṁ ayojjhaṁ?
root_text.mn78:14.2: Idha, thapati, bhikkhu asekhāya sammādiṭṭhiyā samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāsaṅkappena samannāgato hoti, asekhāya sammāvācāya samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammākammantena samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāājīvena samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāvāyāmena samannāgato hoti, asekhāya sammāsatiyā samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāsamādhinā samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāñāṇena samannāgato hoti, asekhāya sammāvimuttiyā samannāgato hoti—
root_text.mn78:14.3: imehi kho ahaṁ, thapati, dasahi dhammehi samannāgataṁ purisapuggalaṁ paññapemi sampannakusalaṁ paramakusalaṁ uttamapattipattaṁ samaṇaṁ ayojjhan”ti.
root_text.mn78:14.5: Attamano pañcakaṅgo thapati bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn78:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn78:1.3: Now at that time the wanderer Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta was residing together with around five hundred wanderers in Mallikā’s single-halled monastery for philosophical debates, hedged by pale-moon ebony trees.
translation_text.mn78:2.1: Then the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga left Sāvatthī in the middle of the day to see the Buddha.
translation_text.mn78:2.3: “It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,
translation_text.mn78:2.5: And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants,
translation_text.mn78:2.7: Why don’t I go to Mallikā’s monastery to visit the wanderer Uggāhamāna?”
translation_text.mn78:3.1: Now at that time, Uggāhamāna was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a colossal racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
translation_text.mn78:3.2: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
translation_text.mn78:3.3: Uggāhamāna saw Pañcakaṅga coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn78:3.5: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
translation_text.mn78:3.6: Here comes Pañcakaṅga, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.
translation_text.mn78:3.7: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing in Sāvatthī.
translation_text.mn78:3.8: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.
translation_text.mn78:3.9: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
translation_text.mn78:4.1: Then Pañcakaṅga approached Uggāhamāna, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn78:4.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. Uggāhamāna said to him:
translation_text.mn78:5.1: “Householder, when an individual person has four qualities I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.
translation_text.mn78:5.3: It’s when they do no bad deeds with their body; speak no bad words; think no bad thoughts; and don’t earn a living by bad livelihood.
translation_text.mn78:5.4: When an individual possesses these four qualities I describe them as an invincible ascetic.”
translation_text.mn78:6.1: Then Pañcakaṅga neither approved nor rejected the wanderer Uggāhamāna’s statement.
translation_text.mn78:6.2: He got up from his seat, thinking,
translation_text.mn78:6.3: “I will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”
translation_text.mn78:7.1: Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
translation_text.mn78:7.2: and informed the Buddha of all that had been discussed.
translation_text.mn78:8.1: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn78:8.2: “Chamberlain, if what Uggāhamāna says is true, a little baby boy is an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.
translation_text.mn78:8.3: For a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘a body’, so how could they possibly do a bad deed with their body, aside from just wriggling?
translation_text.mn78:8.4: And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘speech’, so how could they possibly speak bad words, aside from just crying?
translation_text.mn78:8.5: And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘thought’, so how could they possibly think bad thoughts, aside from just whimpering?
translation_text.mn78:8.6: And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘livelihood’, so how could they possibly earn a living by bad livelihood, aside from their mother’s breast?
translation_text.mn78:8.7: If what Uggāhamāna says is true, a little baby boy is an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.
translation_text.mn78:8.8: When an individual person has four qualities I describe them, not as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment—but as having achieved the same level as a little baby.
translation_text.mn78:8.10: It’s when they do no bad deeds with their body; speak no bad words; think no bad thoughts; and don’t earn a living by bad livelihood.
translation_text.mn78:8.11: When an individual possesses these four qualities I describe them, not as an invincible ascetic, but as having achieved the same level as a little baby.
translation_text.mn78:9.1: When an individual person has ten qualities, chamberlain, I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.
translation_text.mn78:9.2: The following things must be understood, I say. ‘These are unskillful behaviors.’
translation_text.mn78:9.6: ‘Here unskillful behaviors cease without anything left over.’
translation_text.mn78:9.8: ‘Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of unskillful behaviors.’
translation_text.mn78:9.14: ‘Here skillful behaviors cease without anything left over.’
translation_text.mn78:9.16: ‘Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of skillful behaviors.’
translation_text.mn78:9.22: ‘Here unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over.’
translation_text.mn78:9.24: ‘Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of unskillful thoughts.’
translation_text.mn78:9.30: ‘Here skillful thoughts cease without anything left over.’
translation_text.mn78:9.32: ‘Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of skillful thoughts.’
translation_text.mn78:10.1: And what, chamberlain, are unskillful behaviors?
translation_text.mn78:10.2: Unskillful deeds by way of body and speech, and bad livelihood.
translation_text.mn78:10.4: And where do these unskillful behaviors stem from?
translation_text.mn78:10.5: Where they stem from has been stated.
translation_text.mn78:10.6: You should say that they stem from the mind.
translation_text.mn78:10.8: The mind takes many and diverse forms.
translation_text.mn78:10.9: But unskillful behaviors stem from a mind that has greed, hate, and delusion.
translation_text.mn78:10.10: And where do these unskillful behaviors cease without anything left over?
translation_text.mn78:10.11: Their cessation has also been stated.
translation_text.mn78:10.12: It’s when a mendicant gives up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and develops good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind; they give up wrong livelihood and earn a living by right livelihood.
translation_text.mn78:10.13: This is where these unskillful behaviors cease without anything left over.
translation_text.mn78:10.14: And how is someone practicing for the cessation of unskillful behaviors?
translation_text.mn78:10.15: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.
translation_text.mn78:10.16: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.
translation_text.mn78:10.17: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.
translation_text.mn78:10.18: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.
translation_text.mn78:10.19: Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of unskillful behaviors.
translation_text.mn78:11.2: Skillful deeds by way of body and speech, and purified livelihood are included in behavior, I say.
translation_text.mn78:11.4: And where do these skillful behaviors stem from?
translation_text.mn78:11.5: Where they stem from has been stated.
translation_text.mn78:11.6: You should say that they stem from the mind.
translation_text.mn78:11.8: The mind takes many and diverse forms.
translation_text.mn78:11.9: But skillful behaviors stem from a mind that is free from greed, hate, and delusion.
translation_text.mn78:11.10: And where do these skillful behaviors cease without anything left over?
translation_text.mn78:11.11: Their cessation has also been stated.
translation_text.mn78:11.12: It’s when a mendicant behaves ethically, but they are not determined by ethical behavior.
translation_text.mn78:11.13: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where these skillful behaviors cease without anything left over.
translation_text.mn78:11.14: And how is someone practicing for the cessation of skillful behaviors?
translation_text.mn78:11.15: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise …
translation_text.mn78:11.16: so that unskillful qualities are given up …
translation_text.mn78:11.18: so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development.
translation_text.mn78:11.19: Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of skillful behaviors.
translation_text.mn78:12.2: Thoughts of sensuality, of malice, and of cruelty.
translation_text.mn78:12.4: And where do these unskillful thoughts stem from?
translation_text.mn78:12.5: Where they stem from has been stated.
translation_text.mn78:12.6: You should say that they stem from perception.
translation_text.mn78:12.8: Perception takes many and diverse forms.
translation_text.mn78:12.9: Perceptions of sensuality, malice, and cruelty—
translation_text.mn78:12.11: And where do these unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over?
translation_text.mn78:12.12: Their cessation has also been stated.
translation_text.mn78:12.13: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn78:12.14: This is where these unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over.
translation_text.mn78:12.15: And how is someone practicing for the cessation of unskillful thoughts?
translation_text.mn78:12.16: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise …
translation_text.mn78:12.17: so that unskillful qualities are given up …
translation_text.mn78:12.19: so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development.
translation_text.mn78:12.20: Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of unskillful thoughts.
translation_text.mn78:13.2: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
translation_text.mn78:13.4: And where do these skillful thoughts stem from?
translation_text.mn78:13.5: Where they stem from has been stated.
translation_text.mn78:13.6: You should say that they stem from perception.
translation_text.mn78:13.8: Perception takes many and diverse forms.
translation_text.mn78:13.9: Perceptions of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness—
translation_text.mn78:13.11: And where do these skillful thoughts cease without anything left over?
translation_text.mn78:13.12: Their cessation has also been stated.
translation_text.mn78:13.13: It’s when, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn78:13.14: This is where these skillful thoughts cease without anything left over.
translation_text.mn78:13.15: And how is someone practicing for the cessation of skillful thoughts?
translation_text.mn78:13.16: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise …
translation_text.mn78:13.17: so that unskillful qualities are given up …
translation_text.mn78:13.19: so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development.
translation_text.mn78:13.20: Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of skillful thoughts.
translation_text.mn78:14.1: Chamberlain, when an individual person has what ten qualities do I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment?
translation_text.mn78:14.2: It’s when a mendicant has an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.
translation_text.mn78:14.3: When an individual possesses these ten qualities, I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.”
translation_text.mn78:14.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn78:14.5: Satisfied, Pañcakaṅga the chamberlain approved what the Buddha said.
